title: Binary-Coded Decimal (BCD)
description: Learn about BCD, a simple way to represent decimal digits in binary that's used in calculators and digital displays.

sections.title: What is BCD?
sections.content:
Binary-Coded Decimal (BCD) represents each decimal digit separately in 4-bit binary.

**Each decimal digit → 4 binary bits**

**BCD Table:**
```
Decimal  BCD
   0     0000
   1     0001
   2     0010
   3     0011
   4     0100
   5     0101
   6     0110
   7     0111
   8     1000
   9     1001
```

**Example: 25 in BCD**
• Digit 2 → 0010
• Digit 5 → 0101
• Result: 0010 0101

**Comparison:**
• Normal binary: 25 = 11001
• BCD: 25 = 0010 0101

**Why use BCD?**
• Easy to display on digital screens
• Simple conversion to/from decimal
• Used in calculators, digital clocks, meters

sections.title: Reading BCD Numbers
sections.content:
To read BCD, split the binary number into 4-bit groups and convert each group.

**Example: 10010011 in BCD**
• Split: 1001 0011
• 1001 = 9
• 0011 = 3
• Result: 93

**Example: 01010110 in BCD**
• Split: 0101 0110
• 0101 = 5
• 0110 = 6
• Result: 56

**Note:** BCD only uses codes 0000-1001. Codes 1010-1111 are invalid in BCD.

**Common Applications:**
• 7-segment displays
• Digital voltmeters
• Electronic calculators
• Microwave oven displays
• Credit card numbers

hints: Split into 4-bit groups from right to left

questions.questionText: How many bits does BCD use to represent one decimal digit?
questions.explanation: BCD uses 4 bits for each decimal digit (0-9).
5 in BCD is 0101 (same as normal binary for single digits).

questions.questionText: BCD uses more bits than regular binary to represent the same number.
questions.explanation: True. For example, 99 needs 7 bits in binary but 8 bits in BCD. BCD trades efficiency for ease of decimal conversion.
BCD is commonly used in digital displays, calculators, and measurement devices because it's easy to convert to decimal for display.
hints: Think about devices that show numbers

questions.questionText: In BCD, the bit pattern 1010 represents the decimal digit 10.
questions.explanation: False. In BCD, only patterns 0000-1001 (0-9) are valid. 1010 and above are invalid BCD codes.
